contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Damascus" represents the people of the city of Damascus. Alternate translation: "the people of Damascus" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Damascus

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Gilead" represents the people of the region of Gilead. Alternate translation: "the people of Gilead" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Gilead

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Hazael's descendants, who were rulers of the country where Damascus was located. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Hazael

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the ruler of that city or region. Alternate translation: "the ruler of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the man who holds the scepter in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Gaza" represents the people of the region of Gaza. Alternate translation: "the people of Gaza" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Gaza

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Edom" represents the people of the country of Edom. Alternate translation: "the people of Edom" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Edom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the ruler of that city or region. Alternate translation: "the ruler" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the man who holds the scepter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents Yahweh's power that he would use against Ekron. Alternate translation: "I will strike Ekron" or "I will destroy Ekron" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will turn my hand against Ekron

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Ekron" represents the people of the city of Ekron. Alternate translation: "the people of Ekron" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Ekron

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Tyre" represents the people of the city of Tyre. Alternate translation: "the people of Tyre" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Edom" represents the people of the country of Edom. Alternate translation: "the people of Edom" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Edom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the Moabite people. Alternate translation: "the people of Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Moab" represents the people of Moab. Alternate translation: "The people of Moab will die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Moab will die

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the people of Judah. Alternate translation: "the people of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the Israelite people. Alternate translation: "the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metonym for "run away without his weapons" or 2) this is meant literally as "run away wearing no clothes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: flee naked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the whole family" represents to the whole nation. The people of Israel were all descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: "the whole nation" or "the whole clan" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the whole family

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "families" represents nations or people groups. Alternate translation: "all the nations of the earth" or "all the clans on the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all the families of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "violence and destruction" represent things they have taken by being violent and destructive. Alternate translation: "They store up things that they have violently stolen from others" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: They store up violence and destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Jacob's descendants. They were the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "the descendants of Jacob" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: People sinned against God by worshiping false gods at their altars. Here "punish the altars" represents punishing the people by destroying their altars. Alternate translation: "I will also destroy the altars at Bethel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will also punish the altars of Bethel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here having clean teeth represents having no food in the mouth to make the teeth dirty. Alternate translation: "I caused you to starve" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I gave you cleanness of teeth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Giving them "lack of bread" represents causing them to lack bread, and "bread" represents food in general. Alternate translation: "I caused you not to have enough food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: lack of bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "cities" represents the people of those cities. Alternate translation: "The people of two or three cities staggered" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Two or three cities staggered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "afflicted you" represents afflicting their crops. Alternate translation: "I afflicted your crops with blight and mildew" or "I destroyed your crops with blight and mildew" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I afflicted you with blight and mildew

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the sword" represents battle. God killed them by sending enemies to fight against them. Alternate translation: "I made your enemies kill your men in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I killed your young men with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of causing the enemies to steal their horses as if he carried the horses away. Alternate translation: "I made your enemies take away your horses" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: carried away your horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: A stench is a bad smell. The stench coming up to their nostrils represents them smelling something terrible. It can be stated clearly that the smell was from the dead bodies of those who were killed. Alternate translation: "I made you smell the terrible odor of the dead bodies in your camp" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: made the stench of your camp come up to your nostrils

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants. Alternate translation: "you people of Israel" or "you Israelite people group" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Gilgal" represents the people of Gilgal, and going into captivity refers to being captured and taken away. Alternate translation: "For the people of Gilgal will surely be captured and taken away" or "For your enemies will surely capture the people of Gilgal and take them away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: For Gilgal will surely go into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is a metonym for the descendants of Joseph. Here it represents the northern kingdom of Israel, whose two largest tribes were the descendants of Joseph. Alternate translation: "the descendants of Joseph" or "Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "an evil time" represents a time when people are evil and do evil deeds. Alternate translation: "for it is a time when people are evil" or "for people do evil things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: for it is an evil time

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "remnant" refers to people who are still living in Israel after the others are killed or taken away as captives. Here "Joseph" represents the northern kingdom of Israel, whose two largest tribes were the descendants of Joseph. See how you translated "house of Joseph" in [Amos 5:6](../05/06.md). Alternate translation: "the descendants of Joseph who are still alive" or "those of Israel who survive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the remnant of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks as though the Israelites he is speaking to were part of the group that wandered in the wilderness. Alternate translation: "Did your ancestors bring" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Did you bring

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants. See how you translated it in [Amos 5:1](../05/01.md). Alternate translation: "you people of Israel" or "you Israelite people group" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "lifted up the images" represents worshiping them. Alternate translation: "You have worshiped the images of Sikkuth ... and Kaiwan" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You have lifted up the images of Sikkuth ... and Kaiwan

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants. Alternate translation: "the Israelites come" or "the Israelite people group comes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel comes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "throne" is a metonym that represents reign or rule. The people doing evil things, which causes Yahweh to bring disaster on them, is spoken of as if they were causing "violence" to rule them. Alternate translation: "but who are actually causing me to send violent people to destroy you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: and make the throne of violence come near

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Joseph" represents his descendants. Alternate translation: "they do not grieve about the descendants of Joseph whom enemies will soon destroy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: they do not grieve over the ruin of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" represents his descendants. Alternate translation: "I hate the descendants of Jacob because they have become arrogant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I detest the pride of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Lebo Hamath" represents the northern border of Israel, and "brook of the Arabah" represents the southern border. Alternate translation: "from the northern border of your nation to the southern border" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from Lebo Hamath to the brook of the Arabah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" represents his descendants the Israelites. Alternate translation: "how will we Israelites survive? We are so small and weak!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: how will Jacob survive? For he is so small.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" represents his descendants the Israelites. See how you translated this in [Amos 7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: "how will the Israelites survive? We are so small and weak!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: how will Jacob survive? For he is so small.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents an army. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "I will send an army to attack the house of Jeroboam, and the army will destroy the high places of Isaac and the sanctuaries of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: The high places of Isaac will be destroyed, the sanctuaries of Israel will be ruined, and I will rise against the house of Jeroboam with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these represent the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "the descendants of Isaac ... the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Isaac ... Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" represents "family." Translate "Jeroboam" as you did in [Amos 1:1](../01/01.md). Alternate translation: "Jeroboam and his family" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Jeroboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" represents "people." Alternate translation: "Amos is right here among the Israelites, and he is planning to do bad things to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Amos has conspired against you in the middle of the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "land" represents "people." Disrupting the peace is spoken of as if Amos's words were a heavy object that the land could not carry. Alternate translation: "What his is saying disturb the peace among the people" or "His message will cause trouble among the people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The land cannot bear all his words

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents the enemies. Alternate translation: "Enemies will kill Jeroboam" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jeroboam will die by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" represents the family or descendants of Isaac. Alternate translation: "do not speak against the descendants of Isaac" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: do not speak against the house of Isaac

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents enemies. Alternate translation: "enemies will kill your sons and daughters" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: your sons and your daughters will fall by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "pride of Jacob" is a title for Yahweh. Also "Jacob" represents his descendants, the Israelites. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has sworn by himself, saying" or "Yahweh, of whom the Israelites are so proud, has sworn" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh has sworn by the pride of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sin" represents the false god the people worship in Samaria. Alternate translation: "by the false god of Samaria" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: by the sin of Samaria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents an army attacking with their weapons. Alternate translation: "I will send an enemy army to kill the rest of them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I will kill the last of them with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents Yahweh's power. Alternate translation: "I will pull them up from there" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: there my hand will take them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents their enemies. Alternate translation: "there I will cause their enemies to kill them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: there will I give orders to the sword, and it will kill them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents seeing. The phrase "keep my eyes on them" is an idiom that means to watch closely. Alternate translation: "I will watch closely and make sure only bad things happen to them and not good things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I will keep my eyes on them for harm and not for good

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are probably the steps that ancient people imagined led up to God's palace in the heavens. However, some modern versions wish to read a different Hebrew word meaning "palace" or "rooms." Here "his steps" probably is a metonym for God's palace. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he who builds his steps in the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents seeing. Also, Yahweh speaks of himself in third person. Alternate translation: "I, the Lord Yahweh, see that the people of this kingdom are very sinful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.glQuote: the eyes of the Lord Yahweh are on the sinful kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" represents a family. And, "Jacob" represents his descendants. Alternate translation: "the descendants of Jacob" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" represents the people. Alternate translation: "the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sword" represents their enemies. Alternate translation: "Enemies will kill all the sinners of my people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: All the sinners of my people will die by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "name" represents Yahweh. The idiom "called by my name" means they once belonged to Yahweh. This means that in the past the people had conquered and taken control of these territories. Alternate translation: "all the nations that once belonged to me" or "all the nations that I caused the people of Israel to conquer in the past" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: all the nations that are called by my name
